node.title: We Are Not Going to Run Out of Hypocrisy Anytime Soon
node.description: Yet another school shooting, the Supreme Court argument over Roe and much else in American life gives us pause.

node.title: A Glimmer of Justice in Death Penalty States
node.description: The halting of executions and the guilty verdicts in the Ahmaud Arbery case have given us the slightest bit of hope for change.

node.title: New York Religious Schools Face a Vaccine Mandate. Will They Fight It?
node.description: Mayor Bill de Blasio set a vaccine mandate for religious and private schools. Jewish and Catholic leaders are frustrated, and some have predicted legal challenges.

node.title: Why New York Is Unearthing a Brook It Buried a Century Ago
node.description: A plan to “daylight” Tibbetts Brook in the Bronx would be one of the city’s most ambitious green infrastructure improvements.

node.title: What Does the U.S. Owe Separated Families? A Political Quandary Deepens
node.description: Seizing on premature news of potential $450,000 payments, conservatives have added new complications to an effort to compensate migrant families separated by the Trump administration.

node.title: ‘Just Total Chaos’: Floods Bring Death and Devastation to Dairies
node.description: Near-record flooding in Washington State drowned cattle, demolished homes and damaged equipment. Broken supply chains are making it even harder to recover.

node.title: Bearing Witness to Svalbard’s Fragile Splendor
node.description: To visitors, the Norwegian archipelago can seem both ethereal and eternal. But climate change all but guarantees an eventual collapse of its vulnerable ecosystem.

node.title: Companies Linked to Russian Ransomware Hide in Plain Sight
node.description: Cybersecurity experts tracing money paid by American businesses to Russian ransomware gangs found it led to one of Moscow’s most prestigious addresses.

node.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Falls, but Myanmar’s Democratic Hopes Move On
node.description: The ousted civilian leader faces years in custody after being sentenced on the first of several charges. In her absence, a new generation of younger, more progressive politicians is emerging.

node.title: Which States Have Omicron COVID Variant As Four First Cases Reported in One Day
node.description: Laboratory work is ongoing to determine exactly how transmissible and vaccine-resistant the new variant of concern is.

node.title: : Myanmar junta sentences deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi to prison
node.description: Suu Kyi's decades-long push for democracy has made her a Nobel laureate, and a persistent thorn in the side of Myanmar's military overlords. Now she's facing decades in prison.

node.title: An Apartment in the Big City, at Wisconsin Prices
node.description: After living in Madison for six years, they were ready for a change. But they never dreamed they would find a place so close to New York City.

node.title: The Pandemic Has Your Blood Pressure Rising? You’re Not Alone.
node.description: Average blood pressure readings increased as the coronavirus spread, new research suggests. The finding portends medical repercussions far beyond Covid-19.

node.title: Inside Tesla as Elon Musk Pushed an Unflinching Vision for Self-Driving Cars
node.description: The automaker may have undermined safety in designing its Autopilot driver-assistance system to fit its chief executive’s vision, former employees say.

node.title: Listeria Contamination Fears Lead to Over 200,000 Pounds of Pork Recalled
node.description: Alexander & Hornung voluntarily recalled approximately 234,391 pounds of fully cooked ham and pepperoni products.

node.title: 'Your Days are F--king Numbered': Threats Rained Down on Election Officials
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: Today's Google Doodle Celebrates Pizza With Interactive Graphic
node.description: Around five billion pizzas are consumed worldwide every year, with around 350 slices eaten per second in the U.S. alone, according to Google.

node.title: McDonald's Customer Pulls Gun on Employee During Drive-Thru Altercation
node.description: Arthur Walker, 45, threatened the worker who was dealing with a build-up of traffic outside a McDonald's branch, a court was told.

node.title: Who is George Cacioppo? Sony VP Fired After Sting by Vigilante Pedophile Hunters
node.description: George Cacioppo is alleged to have arranged to meet up with a 15-year-old boy in a sting operation by People v. Preds.

node.title: Indonesia's Mount Semeru erupts again, causing rescuers to pause the search for survivors
node.description: Indonesia's national disaster agency says 27 people are still missing but fresh volcanic activity means search and rescue teams have been pulled out until it's deemed safe for them to resume work.

node.title: Cruise disembarks in New Orleans with at least 17 COVID cases
node.description: At least one of the infections on the Norwegian Breakaway was a crew member suspected of having the new Omicron variant.

node.title: Where Omicron Could Have Spread
node.description: The first person in the U.S. with the new variant got sick at home in Minnesota, days after attending an anime convention in Manhattan.

node.title: U.S. says Omicron cases are likely to rise.
node.description: Experts said it is likely that there is already community spread of the variant in the United States.

node.title: Partners or Partners in Crime? Maxwell-Epstein Bond Is Key to Her Trial
node.description: The first week of testimony at Ghislaine Maxwell’s sex-trafficking trial revealed the key question at the center of the case.

node.title: In Its War on Covid-19, China Calls on ‘Little Inoculated Warriors’
node.description: The country regards children as crucial in its quest for herd immunity, but some parents, worried about the vaccines’ safety, are pushing back.

node.title: 'Shocker': $455K road works on major freight route 'melts away'
node.description: The condition of a South Australian road that was resealed earlier this year has motorists concerned - and a local MP has labelled the department explanation 'ridiculous'.

node.title: Theo Hayez inquest told data access reform could save lives
node.description:
Authorities face significant barriers to accessing data that could make all the difference the search for a missing person, the inquest into the disappearance of the Belgian backpacker hears.




A court has heard the family of missing Belgian backpacker Theo Hayez support potential reforms from the 18-year-old's coronial inquest which could help spare other families similar grief.

node.title: Public libraries in Nelson now subject to vaccine pass checks
node.description: People in Nelson need to show vaccine passes to enter public libraries after the Covid-19 outbreak in the region.

node.title: Omicron yet to prove more severe than other variants - WHO
node.description: World Health Organisation spokesperson Dr Margaret Harris says the Covid-19 Omicron variant has "many more mutations" but it is yet to be found to be more severe than previous variants. Audio

node.title: Myanmar’s ousted president and the capital’s mayor were convicted, too.
node.description: The court also convicted U Win Myint, the former president, who was found guilty of violating Covid-19 protocols; and U Myo Aung, the ousted mayor of Naypyidaw, who was convicted of incitement.
